page.title: 03ECOLOGY OF FRILSHAM (1)
page.content: The area is unspoiled by{development} in part because of its distance from a large town and from industry. It is largely as it was a hundred years ago. Minor roads are narrow and winding with steep banks either side. There are many{wild flowers}and an abundance of{animal life}here. The{climate}is equable. The low farms are sheltered by the hills and wooded areas. The { } soil is mainly gravel and chalk with { some peat in the woods and on the Common. There is a{lime quarry}in the south from which agricultural lime is extracted. In the north east there is{ clay once used for brick and tile making. The{River Pang}rises in the clay layers north of Frilsham and flows tranquilly south the east at Bucklebury Ford to join the Thames at Pangbourne. The ford is very popular with playing children and horseriders.
